articles.title: Why the Oracle-OpenAI deal caught Wall Street by surprise
articles.summary: The $300B deal is a reminder that despite Oracle’s legacy status, it shouldn’t be overlooked when it comes to AI infrastructure. But key questions around power and how OpenAI will pay for this remain.

articles.title: Google is a ‘bad actor’ says People CEO, accusing the company of stealing content
articles.summary: People CEO Neil Vogel says Google's AI crawler can't be blocked because it would block the web crawler too. This lets the search giant steal its content for AI.

articles.title: A California bill that would regulate AI companion chatbots is close to becoming law
articles.summary: If SB 243 is enacted, California would become the first state to require operators to implement safety protocols for AI companions and hold companies legally accountable if their chatbots fail to meet those standards.

articles.summary: Generative AI has the potential to transform the finance function. articles.title: Adapting to new threats with proactive risk management
articles.summary: In July 2024, a botched update to the software defenses managed by cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike caused more than 8 million Windows systems to fail. articles.title: Help! My therapist is secretly using ChatGPT

articles.title: Tucker Carlson asks Sam Altman if an OpenAI employee was murdered ‘on your orders’

articles.title: Elon Musk is trying to silence Microsoft employees who criticize Charlie Kirk
articles.summary: Elon Musk is pressing Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella to look into Blizzard employees who criticized Charlie Kirk after his death. Musk’s post quotes an X thread listing names and screenshots of the developers. “What’s going on here, @satyanadella?” Musk said. “These are Microsoft employees,” he added in another post. Musk’s direct question to Nadella follows […]

articles.title: Stellantis cancels Ram 1500 REV as electric truck demand dims
articles.summary: Stellantis announced that it was discontinuing its Ram 1500 REV electric truck, citing slowing sales of heavy-duty electric trucks. The name plate, however, will live on.
